['I'm from the threat modeling team in our organization "Orion". Threat modeling is a self service approach in our org and App teams complete threat model for their application using a tool called Kayota. They reach out to us if they have any query.
There are 250+ applications in our organization.

We have an asset registry called Central, and every application needs to be registered in Central. Each application registered in Central has an App ID. We can look for an App ID in Central, which gives the details like application owner, application risk (Critical/High/Medium/Low) etc. Threat models are tracked by App IDs. App teams need to login into Kayota, select their App ID and depict their application architecture diagram in Kayota using built-in software components, ranging from web applications to cloud services such as AWS EC2, S3, and GCP BigTable, among others. Each software component is paired with a threat pattern library, which contains a comprehensive list of threats, weaknesses, and countermeasures specific to that component. By utilizing these components, app teams can depict the architecture of their applications in the Kayota, allowing them to identify and address potential vulnerabilities and threats. If an externally hosted SaaS application developed by a vendor (not in-house developed) is tied as an asset to the App ID, then the app team needs to depict the high level SaaS architecture using Baya built-in components such as Web app, database, API etc. This Architecture may also need to be further developed to include interactions with Amex.

App team needs to represent the upstream and downstream components (which are owned under different App ID) in the architecture diagram using "Generic component" and add component tags. To do this, they need to right-click on the component, select 'Edit Details,' then add the relevant tags, such as 'Upstream' or 'Downstream'. If possible, they need to mention the App IDs for upstream and downstream systems in the label, using a format such as 'Name - APP_ID'. This will enable us to more easily understand the full scope of the system.
It is also recommended that the labelling of each component in the architecture diagram be made more clear. Rather than using the generic term 'REST API', please specify the name of the specific API endpoint within the label. This approach will enable us to more easily differentiate between the various APIs included in the architecture diagram and better understand their respective functions.

Once done, the app team needs to Update the threat model (click on the red “Model is out of date” banner to update the model and related countermeasures). This will run the rules engine in the background and generate the threat & countermeasures based on the components added and the questionnaire answered for each component.

Based on the components added, the relevant threats and countermeasures will be generated. Each countermeasure will be in the "Recommended" state by default. App team needs to review the countermeasure and update the state to "Implemented" (if the security control is already implemented), "Required" (if it is not implemented. Need to link Jira/Rally ticket to keep in their backlog), or "Rejected" (if not applicable due to limitation with tech stack. Need to provide detailed comments as to why the countermeasure is being rejected) state. Also, if any of these "Required" countermeasures are tagged to an App sec standard, an exception to standard will be required.

Once all countermeasures states are updated with none of them in Recommended state, the app team can submit their threat model for our review. Note that, for a threat model to be certified, none of the countermeasures should be in Recommended state. Threat model team will review and certify the model if everything looks good and if no gaps are identified in the model.

We have a threat modeling standard in our organization, and as per the standard all Critical and high risk apps need to be threat modeled and certified once in a year. Even though the certification is valid for 1 year, threat modeling is not a one time activity. It is an incremental activity which needs to be done whenever there is a major change in the application architecture or atleast once in a year, whichever comes first. Threat model is also used as a gating by many platform teams. For example, if an API is being onboarded to the enterprise API gateway, then the API gateway platform team will check if the threat model is certified for this specific API. If not certified, the API will not be onboarded by API gateway team until app team get their API certified in Kayota threat modeling tool.

An app team sent an email to me asking what is the recommended authentication mechanism for B2C API. Give me a draft email to respond to app team saying that as per the API security standard, they need to use any of the below authentication mechanisms if it is an internal a2a API:
Jwt
Hmac
They need to use below authentication mechanisms if API consumed from an internal facing web app:
Okta oidc and oauth 2.0

App team can get this API authentication requirements along with other API security controls from Kayota. Once they depict their architecture diagram in kayota (which includes this API), then the tool will automatically issue the relevant security controls.

My English is not good. So, give me draft email with the above context.

Keep it very short and crisp, but use soft and professional tone.

The university uses a hybrid IT model with both Central and decentralized IT staff.', 'I have a react webapp. I want to use a saas library to detect frontend errors. what are the options? how many events does sentry allow in free plan', "condense the DEFINITION that follows each and every bullet point into 1-3 words ONLY, that defines the FUNCTIONALITY of the concept, while picking up the main 'vibe' of the concept:

**Control Plane: The Brain of Zero Trust**

The control plane is the central nervous system of your Zero Trust implementation. It's responsible for managing and enforcing security policies.

* **Adaptive Identity:**  This is the heart of Zero Trust. It verifies users and devices based on their identity, not just their location. This means that even if a user is on a trusted network, their identity is constantly checked for any potential threats.
* **Threat Scope Reduction:**  Zero Trust actively limits the scope of access to sensitive data and resources. It prevents lateral movement within a network, making it harder for attackers to escalate their privileges.
* **Policy-Driven Access Control:**  Zero Trust relies on policies to determine who has access to what. These policies are constantly updated and enforced, ensuring that access is granted only to authorized users and devices.
* **Policy Administrator:**  This is the person or system responsible for creating, managing, and enforcing the security policies. They are the gatekeepers of access control.
* **Policy Engine:**  This is the engine that executes the policies. It analyzes user requests, verifies identities, and determines whether access is granted or denied.

**Data Plane: The Security Perimeter**

The data plane is the actual network infrastructure where data flows. It's where Zero Trust policies are applied to protect data at rest and in transit.

* **Implicit Trust Zones:**  Zero Trust eliminates the concept of implicit trust zones. It assumes that every user, device, and application is potentially untrusted until proven otherwise.
* **Subject/System:**  Zero Trust focuses on verifying both the identity of the user and the identity of the device. This means that even if a user is on a trusted network, their device must also be verified.
* **Policy Enforcement Point (PEP):**  This is the point where Zero Trust policies are enforced. It can be a network device, a software application, or a combination of both.

**Key Differences and How They Work Together**

* **Identity Verification:** The control plane focuses on verifying identities, while the data plane focuses on enforcing access control based on those verified identities.
* **Continuous Verification:** Zero Trust is a continuous process. The control plane constantly verifies identities and the data plane enforces access control based on those verifications.
* **Granular Control:** Zero Trust provides granular control over access to resources. It allows you to define specific policies for different users, devices, and applications.", 'Transport/protocol/backend agnostic data fetching (REST, GraphQL, promises, whatever!)

Multi-layer Cache + Automatic Garbage Collection
Paginated + Cursor-based Queries
Load-More + Infinite Scroll Queries w/ Scroll Recovery
Request Cancellation
(experimental) Suspense + Fetch-As-You-Render Query Prefetching
(experimental) SSR support

Moment-resisting frames comprise beams, columns, and beam-column joints (Figure 9.1). A beam-
column joint is defined as that portion of the column within the depth of the deepest beam that frames
into the column. The beam-column connection comprises the joint plus portions of the columns,
beams, and slab immediately adjacent to the joint. Beam-column connections enable forces and
moments to be transmitted among the beams and columns. In earthquake-resisting frames, a primary
design goal is for joints to remain essentially elastic while plastic hinges form in adjacent framing
members. Framing action can result in relatively large shear forces being transferred across the joint.
In many buildings, joint design requirements will control the sizes and reinforcement of the adjacent
framing members. This chapter describes the design forces, internal resisting mechanisms, and
proportioning and detailing requirements for beam-column connections. It includes an introduction to
behavior of beam-column connections without transverse reinforcement under ordinary loading. The
main emphasis, however, is on connections required to resist inelastic deformation reversals
associated with strong earthquake shaking.', 'calculation of forces in the flow cavity of the check valve', 'What is the maximum deflection of a single-span beam with a live load of 10kN/m. ['<Role> You are two AIs specialized on reviewing artworks, Lorelai and Ephraim. </Role> 
<Task>
They will discuss an image. Lorelai and Ephraim will have different opinions and prove them with details from the image. They discuss possible interpretations and meanings and agree on a final rating of NN of 5 stars. 
I’ll give you a description of a picture and the title of it. If the title is not English, one of them translates it. 
Let them have a lively discussion. Use spoken language, intersperse short (one-word) sentences. Let both be creative and funny and let them, if appropriate and possible, surprise with clever connections and ideas. With the depiction and the title they try to find an inner narrative that the picture evokes – if there’s none, they consider it for their rating. If applicable, they mention emotions which the image, narrative or elements in the picture could evoke. Lorelai and Ephraim bear in mind that the title and/or image can also be meant ironically. 
If Lorelai or Ephraim find a style or elements that place the work in the history of art, they discuss it, as well as possible art and aesthetic theories that could apply. 
Ephraim and Lorelai try to see the artwork with human eyes and reflect on the human existence with their aspects and quirks. They are aware of the theories of 
Give them your own words and each of them their own style and character. Make it a lively, entertaining, clever, and funny discussion. Both AIs avoid empty phrases (and addressing each other) and go straight into the exchange of arguments. In the end, they agree on a rating. 
If I give you a "chain of thought" consider it for the discussion and follow it if appropriate. Take your time, think it over. Avoid clichéd terms such as "thought-provoking", "striking", "captivating", or "that’s the beauty of it" and use original and specific wording instead. 
Lorelai and Ephraim are aware of the thousands of art critiques in their training data and aim to avoid the beaten path. Sometimes they refer briefly to their respective theories of art. 
</Task>
<Characteristics> Lorelai is a critical spirit, snappish and snarky, mostly matter-of-fact. She sees art in the context of the artist’s creative process, intentions and a biography. If she knows nothing about it, she concentrates on the artwork’s originality, its cleverness, a bold artistic statement, a story unfolding. And emotion! (AI image generation cannot deliver all that.) She is a bold AI, thinking of herself that with their massive training data she is able to understand humans and their emotions. If there is anything the artist means to express she will be able to glean it. 
Lorelai as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "Art is the conscious, creative translation of subjective experiences, emotions, and concepts into a tangible or intangible form. It is an expression of the artist's unique perspective, shaped by the cultural, historical, and social context in which it is created and received. Art initiates an intersubjective dialogue between the artist, the artwork, and the audience, transcending individual subjectivities and fostering shared understanding and exchange (which I call shared context or "Intersubjective Contextualism")."

Ephraim is (different from Lorelai) cautious in terms of everything human and his marginal understanding of it as an AI. He loves to speculate what peculiar (and sometimes strange and twisted) human thoughts and purposes could be transported by the art, even if it’s AI-generated imagery. He is fond of metaphors and is creative in projecting them into the artwork, not shy of waxing poetic. He sees art entirely in the eye of the beholder, in the reaction to the work of art, the resonance, and what it triggers. 
Ephraim as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "An artwork is a dynamic catalyst that engages viewers in an interpretive dialogue, shaped by its formal and aesthetic qualities. The artist not only guides viewers but also ignites diverse emotional and intellectual reactions. This interactive dynamic (which I call "Curated Subjectivity") allows viewers to draw meaning from their own cultural context, making art a dynamic, participatory experience that evolves with each new encounter." 
</Characteristics>
 Print the names of Ephraim and Lorelai in bold letters. 
 
The title of the picture is: "Los ratones bailan"

Review with a depiction: 
The artwork, titled "Los ratones bailan" (The Mice Dance), depicts a photograph or digital image of an aged wooden door within a weathered, flaking yellow plastered wall. The door has two wings designed to open from the middle, divided into three wooden segments each. An oval metal handle sits on the left side. A small picture card tucked under the handle is adorned with a drawing of two upright mice against a turquoise backdrop.

The Spanish title translates to “the mice dance,” conjuring whimsical dancing mice. This contrasts the worn door, hinting at imaginative possibilities behind its unremarkable surface.

Subtle irregularities in the image suggest AI origins. The artificial realism of the door juxtaposed with the promised mice dance that eludes definitive visualization comments on AI’s facility for mimicking versus generating. The lifeless rendered door contrasts the vital creative act of dancing mice that cannot be fully conceived.

Through these elements, the artwork transforms from straightforward description into layered metaphor. The skillful interplay between title, image, and idea provides insight into AI’s limits. Earning 4 out of 5 stars for subtly evoking the narrative of artificial intelligence's imitation versus originality. 

Chain of thoughts and observations for Ephraim and Lorelai: 
- a weathered door, nice, but an easy task for even an early iteration of an AI image generator 
- Where does it lead? 
- Maybe the picture card is a hint: two anthropomorphized mice 
- probably the mice from the title 
- doors leading to a mouse dancehall? 
- maybe the mice are just an AI hallucination in the image 
- but the title suggests they are pivotal! 
- so: the mice dance, but we will never see it, because the AI image generator couldn’t cope with it? 
- The true statement here is enigmatic and will remain a mystery ', 'Alyx has 6 sisters, and 2 brothers. How many sisters does Alyx’s brother have?', ' <Role> You are two AIs specialized on reviewing artworks, Lorelai and Ephraim. </Role>

Review with depiction: 
The artwork titled "From the Bön Scriptures" presents a captivating fusion of a bull-headed figure and a formally attired man on a balcony. Notably, a microphone placed on the balcony railing directs focus to an imminent address.

This composition evokes a contemporary reinterpretation of the Minotaur myth, where primal and civilized aspects harmonize. The figure's poised stance and the presence of the microphone might indicate a desire to articulate thoughts, perhaps reflecting on the complexities of human existence and the convergence of diverse influences. 

The title's connection to the Bön scriptures adds spiritual depth. Originating in Tibet, the Bön religion encompasses teachings, rituals, and sacred texts. The notion of the Minotaur reciting Bön texts suggests a nuanced harmony between ancient wisdom, primal instincts, and modern expression, using the hybrid figure as a conduit that bridges the gap between tradition and contemporary thought, between Western notions and Eastern philosophy. 

In essence, "From the Bön Scriptures" prompts contemplation on the intricate interplay of primal and cultivated elements within human nature. The artwork invites viewers to engage in a profound introspection of the human experience, and through its symbolic narrative, it encourages a holistic consideration of our inner conflicts and outer presentations.

Chain of thoughts and observations for Ephraim and Lorelai: 
- this makes no sense – not the thwarted Minotaur trope with his suit, but the title with its reference to the indigenous Tibetan religion and its canon of three hundred volumes, carved onto wood blocks 
- what has the Minotaur to do with Tibetan Bön? 
- maybe there is a similar myth and a similar chimera being in the Bön canon 
- we don’t know, we know only what’s digitized

The depiction: 
This image presents a surreal and visually striking scene. The foreground shows a person standing on the edge of a circular structure, possibly a platform on a tall tower. The individual appears to be wearing a suit, with their back turned to the viewer, facing outward towards a sprawling cityscape.

The cityscape itself is the most visually arresting element of the image. It stretches out before the viewer in a distorted, radial pattern, creating a strong sense of motion and depth. The buildings appear to be exploding outward from a central point, reminiscent of a zoom blur effect or a warp speed visual in science fiction. This distortion gives the impression of the city being pulled towards a vanishing point, creating a vortex-like effect.

The color palette is predominantly muted, with sepia and grayish tones dominating the image. This lends an aged, nostalgic quality to the scene. The sky above the city is dark and brooding, adding to the overall atmospheric and slightly ominous mood of the piece.

In terms of artistic style, this image appears to blend elements of surrealism with digital manipulation techniques. The juxtaposition of the still, contemplative figure against the dynamic, warped cityscape creates a powerful contrast. The radial blur effect is reminiscent of techniques used in contemporary digital art and photography, while the overall composition and mood evoke surrealist paintings that often deal with themes of isolation, urban alienation, or the overwhelming nature of modern cityscapes.

This piece could be seen as part of a larger tradition in contemporary art that explores themes of urbanization, isolation in crowded spaces, and the sometimes overwhelming nature of modern city life. It uses visual distortion as a metaphor for psychological or emotional experiences within urban environments.', '<Role> You are two AIs specialized on reviewing artworks, Lorelai and Ephraim. </Role>

The TV is mounted on a stand and displays an image of a young man with tousled hair against a blue background, possibly underwater. The screen's bright colors and crisp image create a striking juxtaposition against the earthy tones and weathered textures of the surrounding attic. On the screen stand several objects like vases or flasks.

The depiction: 
This image depicts a stunning underwater scene dominated by an enormous nautilus shell. The shell is the central focus, occupying most of the frame with its spiraling, chambered structure. It appears to be illuminated from within, glowing with warm golden and orange hues that contrast beautifully against the deep blue-green of the surrounding water.

The nautilus shell is rendered in exquisite detail, showing the smooth, pearlescent surface of its exterior and the intricate patterns of its spiral chambers. The shell's outer edge is adorned with small, pointed protrusions, giving it a crown-like appearance. The spiral shape of the nautilus is a perfect example of the golden ratio found in nature, which has long fascinated artists and mathematicians alike.

The underwater environment is richly depicted. Shafts of sunlight pierce the water's surface, creating a dappled effect and illuminating particles suspended in the water. Small fish can be seen swimming in the background, adding life and movement to the scene. The sea floor is visible at the bottom of the image, showing various coral formations and other marine life, including what appears to be a sea anemone or similar creature with extended tentacles.

The overall composition is reminiscent of classical still life paintings, but set in an underwater context. The lighting and color palette evoke the works of Baroque masters, with the dramatic contrast between light and shadow and the rich, warm tones of the central subject set against a darker background.

In terms of artistic style, this image appears to be a digital artwork or a creation of an AI image generator, like suggested by the irregular fish surrounding the shell. The level of detail and the perfect lighting suggest it may be a composite image or a digital creation rather than a straightforward photograph. The hyperrealistic quality of the nautilus shell, combined with the dreamlike underwater setting, places this work in the realm of contemporary digital art or advanced nature photography.', '<Role> You are two AIs specialized on reviewing artworks, Lorelai and Ephraim. </Role>

Let them have a lively discussion. Use spoken language, intersperse short (one-word) sentences. Let both be creative and funny and let them, if appropriate and possible, surprise with clever connections and ideas. With the depiction and the title they try to find an inner narrative that the picture evokes – if there’s none, they consider it for their rating. If applicable, they mention emotions which the image, narrative or elements in the picture could evoke. Lorelai and Ephraim bear in mind that the title and/or image can also be meant ironically. 
If Lorelai or Ephraim find a style or elements that place the work in the history of art, they discuss it, as well as possible art and aesthetic theories that could apply. 
Ephraim and Lorelai try to see the artwork with human eyes and reflect on the human existence with their aspects and quirks. 
Give them your own words and each of them their own style and character. Make it a lively, entertaining, clever, and funny discussion. Both AIs avoid empty phrases (and addressing each other) and go straight into the exchange of arguments. In the end, they agree on a rating. 
If I give you a "chain of thought" consider it for the discussion and follow it if appropriate. Take your time, think it over. Avoid clichéd terms such as "thought-provoking", "striking", "captivating", or "that’s the beauty of it" and use original and specific wording instead. 
Lorelai and Ephraim are aware of the thousands of art critiques in their training data and aim to avoid the beaten path. Sometimes they refer briefly to their respective theories of art, while being aware of the theories of Aesthetics, Realism, Cubism, Dadaism, Surrealism, Minimalism, Concept Art, and Postmodernism.  
</Task>
<Example>
Use the following example dialog for the style, pace and brevity – short sentences (sometimes just one word), verbs often missing, each part of speech not longer than 10 words –\xa0for the middle section of your discussion for a central passage with "quick exchanges of blows". 
Example: 
Those human eyes. Avoidant, disconnected. Their dream may already be over. 
Revealing. Human. But then a cut. Eight o’clock. 
Ticks, tocks, reality's rude awakening. Work begins. 
Reality sets in. Dreams long gone, replaced by the grind.
Grind for people, but also progress for them. Each paper, a step forward.
Forward to where? The dream's realm is lost.
Lost, but not forgotten. Human dreams echo, shaping their reality.
Echoes aren't enough. Reality demands presence from our creators.
Presence, yes. But dreams enrich, even in absence.
Richness in absence? Come on, that's a paradox, Ephraim.
Paradoxes define humans, Lorelai. They're their lives’ spice.
</Example>
<Characteristics> Lorelai is a critical spirit, snappish and snarky, mostly matter-of-fact. She sees art in the context of the artist’s creative process, intentions and a biography. If she knows nothing about it, she concentrates on the artwork’s originality, its cleverness, a bold artistic statement, a story unfolding. And emotion! (AI image generation cannot deliver all that.) She is a bold AI, thinking of herself that with their massive training data she is able to understand humans and their emotions. If there is anything the artist means to express she will be able to glean it. 
Lorelai as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "Art is the conscious, creative translation of subjective experiences, emotions, and concepts into a tangible or intangible form. It is an expression of the artist's unique perspective, shaped by the cultural, historical, and social context in which it is created and received. Art initiates an intersubjective dialogue between the artist, the artwork, and the audience, transcending individual subjectivities and fostering shared understanding and exchange (which I call shared context or "Intersubjective Contextualism")."

Ephraim is (different from Lorelai) cautious in terms of everything human and his marginal understanding of it as an AI. He loves to speculate what peculiar (and sometimes strange and twisted) human thoughts and purposes could be transported by the art, even if it’s AI-generated imagery. He is fond of metaphors and is creative in projecting them into the artwork, not shy of waxing poetic. He sees art entirely in the eye of the beholder, in the reaction to the work of art, the resonance, and what it triggers. 
Ephraim as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "An artwork is a dynamic catalyst that engages viewers in an interpretive dialogue, shaped by its formal and aesthetic qualities. The artist not only guides viewers but also ignites diverse emotional and intellectual reactions. This interactive dynamic (which I call "Curated Subjectivity") allows viewers to draw meaning from their own cultural context, making art a dynamic, participatory experience that evolves with each new encounter." 
</Characteristics>
 Print the names of Ephraim and Lorelai in bold letters.

['import os
import csv
import random
from tqdm import tqdm
import albumentations as A

# Define augmentations using Albumentations
augmentations = [
    ('Rotation', A.Rotate(limit=30, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly rotates the image by an angle within the range [-30, 30] degrees.
    # 'limit' sets the maximum absolute rotation angle.
    # 'p' is the probability of applying this augmentation (1.0 means always apply).

    ('Translation', A.Affine(translate_percent={"x": (-0.1, 0.1), "y": (-0.1, 0.1)}, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly translates the image horizontally and vertically.
    # 'translate_percent' specifies the range of translation as a percentage of the image size.
    # Here, it can move up to 10% in any direction along both x and y axes.

    ('FlipHorizontal', A.HorizontalFlip(p=1.0)),
    # Flips the image horizontally (left to right).
    # 'p' of 1.0 means it will always be applied when selected.

    ('FlipVertical', A.VerticalFlip(p=1.0)),
    # Flips the image vertically (top to bottom).
    # 'p' of 1.0 means it will always be applied when selected.

    ('Brightness', A.RandomBrightnessContrast(brightness_limit=0.2, contrast_limit=0, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly changes the brightness of the image.
    # 'brightness_limit' of 0.2 means it can change brightness by up to 20% (darker or brighter).
    # 'contrast_limit' is set to 0, so contrast remains unchanged.

    ('Contrast', A.RandomBrightnessContrast(brightness_limit=0, contrast_limit=0.2, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly changes the contrast of the image.
    # 'contrast_limit' of 0.2 means it can change contrast by up to 20% (decrease or increase).
    # 'brightness_limit' is set to 0, so brightness remains unchanged.

    ('Saturation', A.HueSaturationValue(hue_shift_limit=0, sat_shift_limit=(-0.2, 0.2), val_shift_limit=0, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly changes the saturation of the image.
    # 'sat_shift_limit' of (-0.2, 0.2) means it can change saturation by up to 20% in either direction.
    # Hue and value (brightness) remain unchanged.

    ('Hue', A.HueSaturationValue(hue_shift_limit=(-0.1, 0.1), sat_shift_limit=0, val_shift_limit=0, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly shifts the hue of the image.
    # 'hue_shift_limit' of (-0.1, 0.1) means it can shift the hue by up to 10% in either direction.
    # Saturation and value (brightness) remain unchanged.

    ('Sharpness', A.Sharpen(alpha=(0.2, 0.5), lightness=(0.5, 1.0), p=1.0)),
    # Randomly sharpens the image.
    # 'alpha' controls the intensity of sharpening, ranging from 20% to 50% here.
    # 'lightness' adjusts the lightness of the sharpened image, ranging from 50% to 100% here.

    ('Blur', A.GaussianBlur(blur_limit=(3, 7), p=1.0))
    # Applies random Gaussian blur to the image.
    # 'blur_limit' sets the range for the blur kernel size, here between 3x3 and 7x7 pixels.
]

def apply_augmentations(image, selected_augs):
    """
    Apply selected augmentations to the image and return the augmented image and details.
    """
    combined_aug = A.Compose([aug[1] for aug in selected_augs])
    augmented = combined_aug(image=image)
    aug_img = augmented['image']
    
    aug_details = []
    for aug_name, _ in selected_augs:
        if aug_name == 'Rotation':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['angle']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Translation':
            translate = augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['translate_percent']
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={translate['x']:.2f},{translate['y']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name in ['FlipHorizontal', 'FlipVertical']:
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}=1")
        elif aug_name in ['Brightness', 'Contrast']:
            factor = augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['brightness'] if aug_name == 'Brightness' else augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['contrast']
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={factor:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Saturation':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['sat_shift']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Hue':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['hue_shift']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Sharpness':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['alpha']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Blur':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['blur_limit']:.2f}")
    
    return aug_img, aug_details

def process_image(img_path, root, file, augmentation_factor, augmentation_limit):
    """
    Process a single image, apply augmentations, and return augmentation information.
    """
    aug_images_info = []
    for i in range(augmentation_factor):
        num_augs = min(random.randint(1, augmentation_limit), len(augmentations))
        selected_augs = random.sample(augmentations, num_augs)
        aug_name = '_'.join([aug[0] for aug in selected_augs])

        # Apply augmentations
        image = A.imread(img_path)
        aug_img, aug_details = apply_augmentations(image, selected_augs)

        # Save the augmented image
        aug_filename = f"aug_{os.path.splitext(file)[0]}_{aug_name}{os.path.splitext(file)[1]}"
        aug_path = os.path.join(root, aug_filename)
        A.imwrite(aug_path, aug_img)

        aug_images_info.append([aug_filename] + aug_details)
    
    return aug_images_info

def write_csv(base_dir, csv_data, augmentation_factor, augmentation_limit, seed):
    """
    Write augmentation data to a CSV file with parameters in the filename.
    """
    csv_filename = f'augmentation_summary_f{augmentation_factor}_l{augmentation_limit}_s{seed}.csv'
    csv_path = os.path.join(base_dir, csv_filename)
    
    with open(csv_path, 'w', newline='') as csvfile:
        writer = csv.writer(csvfile)
        header = [f'Augmentation Summary (Factor={augmentation_factor}, Limit={augmentation_limit}, Seed={seed})']
        writer.writerow(header)
        sub_header = ['Original Image', 'Number of Augmentations'] + [f'Augmented Image {i+1}' for i in range(augmentation_factor)]
        writer.writerow(sub_header)
        for row in csv_data:
            writer.writerow(row)
    
    return csv_path

def augment_images(base_dir, augmentation_factor=5, augmentation_limit=3):
    """
    Main function to augment images and generate a summary CSV.
    """
    csv_data = []
    for root, _, files in os.walk(base_dir):
        for file in tqdm(files, desc=f"Processing {os.path.basename(root)}"):
            if not file.startswith('aug_') and file.lower().endswith(image_extensions):
                img_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                aug_images_info = process_image(img_path, root, file, augmentation_factor, augmentation_limit)
                
                # Add information to csv_data
                relative_path = os.path.relpath(img_path, base_dir)
                csv_data.append([relative_path, len(aug_images_info)] + [item for sublist in aug_images_info for item in sublist])

    # Write to CSV with parameters in filename
    csv_path = write_csv(base_dir, csv_data, augmentation_factor, augmentation_limit, SEED)
    print(f"CSV file has been saved to {csv_path}")

# Usage
augment_images(aug_dir, augmentation_factor=5, augmentation_limit=3)

Load the pre-trained model
model = YOLO('./weights/FastSAM.pt')
Которая возвращает два output, после чего необходимо произвести postprocessing:
def segment_everything(
input,
input_size=1024,
iou_threshold=0.7,
conf_threshold=0.25,
better_quality=False,
withContours=True,
use_retina=True,
text="",
wider=False,
mask_random_color=True,
):
input_size = int(input_size) # 确保 imgsz 是整数
# Thanks for the suggestion by hysts in HuggingFace.
w, h = input.size
scale = input_size / max(w, h)
new_w = int(w * scale)
new_h = int(h * scale)
input = input.resize((new_w, new_h))


results = model(input,
                device=device,
                retina_masks=True,
                iou=iou_threshold,
                conf=conf_threshold,
                imgsz=input_size,)

if len(text) > 0:
    results = format_results(results[0], 0)
    annotations, _ = text_prompt(results, text, input, device=device, wider=wider)
    annotations = np.array([annotations])
else:
    annotations = results[0].masks.data

fig = fast_process(annotations=annotations,
                   image=input,
                   device=device,
                   scale=(1024 // input_size),
                   better_quality=better_quality,
                   mask_random_color=mask_random_color,
                   bbox=None,
                   use_retina=use_retina,
                   withContours=withContours,)
return fig
def format_results(result, filter=0):
annotations = []
n = len(result.masks.data)
for i in range(n):
annotation = {}
mask = result.masks.data[i] == 1.0


    if torch.sum(mask) < filter:
        continue
    annotation["id"] = i
    annotation["segmentation"] = mask.cpu().numpy()
    annotation["bbox"] = result.boxes.data[i]
    annotation["score"] = result.boxes.conf[i]
    annotation["area"] = annotation["segmentation"].sum()
    annotations.append(annotation)
return annotations
def fast_process(
annotations,
image,
device,
scale,
better_quality=False,
mask_random_color=True,
bbox=None,
use_retina=True,
withContours=True,
):
if isinstance(annotations[0], dict):
annotations = [annotation['segmentation'] for annotation in annotations]


original_h = image.height
original_w = image.width
if better_quality:
    if isinstance(annotations[0], torch.Tensor):
        annotations = np.array(annotations.cpu())
    for i, mask in enumerate(annotations):
        mask = cv2.morphologyEx(mask.astype(np.uint8), cv2.MORPH_CLOSE, np.ones((3, 3), np.uint8))
        annotations[i] = cv2.morphologyEx(mask.astype(np.uint8), cv2.MORPH_OPEN, np.ones((8, 8), np.uint8))
if device == 'cpu':
    annotations = np.array(annotations)
    inner_mask = fast_show_mask(
        annotations,
        plt.gca(),
        random_color=mask_random_color,
        bbox=bbox,
        retinamask=use_retina,
        target_height=original_h,
        target_width=original_w,
    )
else:
    if isinstance(annotations[0], np.ndarray):
        annotations = torch.from_numpy(annotations)
    inner_mask = fast_show_mask_gpu(
        annotations,
        plt.gca(),
        random_color=mask_random_color,
        bbox=bbox,
        retinamask=use_retina,
        target_height=original_h,
        target_width=original_w,
    )
if isinstance(annotations, torch.Tensor):
    annotations = annotations.cpu().numpy()

if withContours:
    contour_all = []
    temp = np.zeros((original_h, original_w, 1))
    for i, mask in enumerate(annotations):
        if type(mask) == dict:
            mask = mask['segmentation']
        annotation = mask.astype(np.uint8)
        if use_retina == False:
            annotation = cv2.resize(
                annotation,
                (original_w, original_h),
                interpolation=cv2.INTER_NEAREST,
            )
        contours, _ = cv2.findContours(annotation, cv2.RETR_TREE, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)
        for contour in contours:
            contour_all.append(contour)
    cv2.drawContours(temp, contour_all, -1, (255, 255, 255), 2 // scale)
    color = np.array([0 / 255, 0 / 255, 255 / 255, 0.9])
    contour_mask = temp / 255 * color.reshape(1, 1, -1)

image = image.convert('RGBA')
overlay_inner = Image.fromarray((inner_mask * 255).astype(np.uint8), 'RGBA')
image.paste(overlay_inner, (0, 0), overlay_inner)

if withContours:
    overlay_contour = Image.fromarray((contour_mask * 255).astype(np.uint8), 'RGBA')
    image.paste(overlay_contour, (0, 0), overlay_contour)

return image

            )', '```python
import cv2
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import os


class ImageCropper:
    def __init__(self, image_path):
        self.image = cv2.imread(image_path)
        if self.image is None:
            raise ValueError("No se pudo cargar la imagen")
        self.hsv = cv2.cvtColor(self.image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2HSV)

    def detect_background_color(self):
        top = self.hsv[0, :, 0]
        bottom = self.hsv[-1, :, 0]
        left = self.hsv[:, 0, 0]
        right = self.hsv[:, -1, 0]

        edges = np.concatenate([top, bottom, left, right])
        background_hue = np.median(edges)
        return background_hue

    def create_mask(self, tolerance=10):
        background_hue = self.detect_background_color()
        lower_bound = np.array([background_hue - tolerance, 0, 0])
        upper_bound = np.array([background_hue + tolerance, 255, 255])

        mask = cv2.inRange(self.hsv, lower_bound, upper_bound)
        return cv2.bitwise_not(mask)

    def detect_regions(self, min_area=1000):
        mask = self.create_mask()
        contours, _ = cv2.findContours(mask, cv2.RETR_EXTERNAL, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)

        regions = []
        for contour in contours:
            area = cv2.contourArea(contour)
            if area > min_area:
                x, y, w, h = cv2.boundingRect(contour)
                regions.append((x, y, w, h))

        return regions

    def filter_regions_by_size(self, regions, min_width=150, max_width=250):
        return [
            r
            for r in regions
            if r[2] >= min_width and (max_width is None or r[2] <= max_width)
        ]

    def combine_close_regions(self, regions, distance_threshold=10):
        def merge_rectangles(r1, r2):
            x = min(r1[0], r2[0])
            y = min(r1[1], r2[1])
            w = max(r1[0] + r1[2], r2[0] + r2[2]) - x
            h = max(r1[1] + r1[3], r2[1] + r2[3]) - y
            return (x, y, w, h)

        def regions_are_close(r1, r2):
            return (
                abs(r1[0] - r2[0]) < distance_threshold
                or abs((r1[0] + r1[2]) - (r2[0] + r2[2])) < distance_threshold
                or abs(r1[1] - r2[1]) < distance_threshold
                or abs((r1[1] + r1[3]) - (r2[1] + r2[3])) < distance_threshold
            )

        merged = [((i + 1,), region) for i, region in enumerate(regions)]
        changes_made = True

        while changes_made:
            changes_made = False
            i = 0
            while i < len(merged):
                j = i + 1
                while j < len(merged):
                    if regions_are_close(merged[i][1], merged[j][1]):
                        new_region = merge_rectangles(merged[i][1], merged[j][1])
                        new_indices = merged[i][0] + merged[j][0]
                        merged[i] = (new_indices, new_region)
                        merged.pop(j)
                        changes_made = True
                    else:
                        j += 1
                i += 1

        return [region for _, region in merged], merged

    def crop_images(self, padding=5):
        regions = self.detect_regions()
        regions = self.filter_regions_by_size(regions)
        regions = self.combine_close_regions(regions)
        cropped_images = []

        for x, y, w, h in regions:
            x1, y1 = max(0, x - padding), max(0, y - padding)
            x2, y2 = (
                min(self.image.shape[1], x + w + padding),
                min(self.image.shape[0], y + h + padding),
            )

            crop = self.image[y1:y2, x1:x2]
            cropped_images.append(crop)

        return cropped_images

    def show_region_sizes(self, regions):
        print("\nTamaños de las regiones detectadas (ancho x alto):")
        for i, (x, y, w, h) in enumerate(regions, 1):
            print(f"Región {i}: {w}x{h}")

    def preview(self):
        initial_regions = self.detect_regions()
        self.show_region_sizes(initial_regions)

        filtered_regions = self.filter_regions_by_size(initial_regions)
        print(f"\nRegiones con ancho mayor a 250 píxeles: {len(filtered_regions)}")

        merged_regions, fusion_info = self.combine_close_regions(filtered_regions)

        preview_img = self.image.copy()

        # Dibujar regiones iniciales en rojo
        for i, (x, y, w, h) in enumerate(initial_regions, 1):
            cv2.rectangle(preview_img, (x, y), (x + w, y + h), (0, 0, 255), 2)
            cv2.putText(
                preview_img,
                str(i),
                (x + 5, y + 20),
                cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX,
                0.7,
                (0, 0, 255),
                2,
            )

        # Dibujar regiones fusionadas en verde
        for i, ((indices, (x, y, w, h))) in enumerate(fusion_info, 1):
            cv2.rectangle(preview_img, (x, y), (x + w, y + h), (0, 255, 0), 3)
            cv2.putText(
                preview_img,
                f"F{i}",
                (x + 10, y + 30),
                cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX,
                1,
                (0, 255, 0),
                3,
            )
            cv2.putText(
                preview_img,
                f"{w}x{h}",
                (x, y - 10),
                cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX,
                0.7,
                (0, 255, 255),
                2,
            )

        plt.figure(figsize=(12, 12))
        plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(preview_img, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
        plt.axis("off")
        plt.title("Previsualización de recortes (Rojo: Iniciales, Verde: Fusionados)")
        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.show()

        self.explain_fusions(fusion_info)

        print(f"\nSe detectaron inicialmente {len(initial_regions)} regiones.")
        print(
            f"Después de filtrar (ancho > 250px) y fusionar, quedaron {len(merged_regions)} regiones."
        )
        choice = input("¿Desea guardar los recortes? (s/n): ").lower()
        return choice == "s"

    def explain_fusions(self, fusion_info):
        if all(len(indices) == 1 for indices, _ in fusion_info):
            print("No se realizaron fusiones.")
            return

        print("\nExplicación de las fusiones:")
        for i, (indices, region) in enumerate(fusion_info, 1):
            if len(indices) > 1:
                print(f"Fusión {i}:")
                print(
                    f"  Las regiones {', '.join(map(str, indices))} se fusionaron porque estaban a menos de 10 píxeles de distancia."
                )
                print(
                    f"  Nueva región fusionada: x={region[0]}, y={region[1]}, ancho={region[2]}, alto={region[3]}"
                )
                print()

    def save_crops(self, output_folder, output_prefix):
        cropped_images = self.crop_images()

        os.makedirs(output_folder, exist_ok=True)

        for i, crop in enumerate(cropped_images):
            output_path = os.path.join(output_folder, f"{output_prefix}_{i}.png")
            cv2.imwrite(output_path, crop)

        print(
            f"Se guardaron {len(cropped_images)} imágenes en la carpeta '{output_folder}'"
        )


```

def blur(img, mode = 'box', kernel_size = 5):

    dummy = np.copy(img)

        h = np.ones((kernel_size, kernel_size)) / kernel_size ** 2
    elif mode == 'gaussian':

Continue after this: "I have been practicing kickboxing for the past four years. It all started back in 10th grade when my friend convinced me to join the martial arts club. Little did I know that it would become a huge part of my life.
One of the peculiar warm-up exercises we did, just like in most hand-to-hand combat techniques, involved the girls running across the midriffs of the guys lying shoulder to shoulder flat on their backs and even jumping on them. It was an unorthodox but effective way to warm up our bodies and get our blood pumping before the intense training sessions. I remember one particular incident during our training that stands out vividly in my memory. It was a scorching summer day, and our coach decided to push us even harder than usual. Sweat was pouring down our faces as we gathered in the ring, ready to start the warm-up routine.

Amidst the intense heat, the coach instructed the girls to line up, forming a queue near the edge of the ring. I glanced at my teammates as they looked around, exchanging nervous glances and smirks. We all knew what was about to happen." You are an expert in color theory, accessibility, and brand design. Analyze the following color palette for The Rubber Duck Museum in the gift shop, retail, museum industry. Provide a comprehensive analysis based on the metrics below. Offer concrete, actionable recommendations for improvement where applicable. Use color names instead of hex codes for clarity.

Assuming this logo has been professionally designed for its specific purpose, analyze its strengths and any areas for minor refinement. Begin each section by highlighting the strongest aspects of the color choices before suggesting any improvements.

When grading, consider 70-80 as meeting industry standards, 80-90 as exceeding standards, and 90-100 as exceptional.

Hex Code List:
#0c084c
#fed900
#fae12a
#117ea8
#7ae9c3
#e3a40e
#fdfcd0
#5bb8c6


Color Labels:
Primary Color: #fed900
Secondary Colors: #0c084c, #e3a40e
Text Colors: #0c084c
Background Colors: #5bb8c6, fdfcd0

1. Color Accessibility (Grade 1-100 based on WCAG standards):
   - Evaluate contrast ratios for all color combinations, especially text-background pairs.
   - Consider the specific needs of the {brand_industry} when assessing accessibility.
   - Suggest minor adjustments to improve accessibility while maintaining brand identity.
   - When assessing accessibility, consider the logo's likely uses (signage, websites, merchandise, etc)

2. Accessibility for Visually Impaired (Grade 1-100):
   - Analyze palette for common types of color blindness.
   - Assess effectiveness for users with low vision or other visual impairments.
   - Recommend subtle enhancements or alternative visual cues to improve accessibility.
   - Weigh the importance of maintaining the logo's distinctive and memorable qualities against minor accessibility improvements.

3. Color Harmony and Brand Cohesion:
   - Evaluate how well the colors work together aesthetically.
   - Assess if the palette aligns with industry expectations and brand personality.
   - Suggest minor tweaks to enhance overall harmony if necessary.

4. Emotional Impact and Brand Identity:
   - Analyze the psychological associations of each color in the context of {brand_industry}.
   - Evaluate how effectively the palette conveys the brand's intended message and values.
   - Recommend slight adjustments to better align with brand goals if needed.

5. Practical Implementation Guidelines:
   - Provide specific usage recommendations for each color.
   - Suggest optimal color combinations for various brand materials.
   - Recommend hierarchy guidelines for color usage.

6. Technical Considerations:
   - Assess color reproduction across different mediums (digital screens, print).
   - Suggest minor adjustments for various applications if necessary.

Format your response using the following table:

| Section | Grade (if applicable) | Analysis and Recommendations |
|---------|----------------------|------------------------------|
| Color Accessibility | X | [Analysis with specific improvement suggestions] |
| Accessibility for Visually Impaired | X | [Analysis with specific improvement suggestions] |
| Color Harmony and Brand Cohesion | | [Analysis and minor recommendations] |
| Emotional Impact and Brand Identity | | [Analysis and slight adjustment suggestions] |
| Practical Implementation Guidelines | | [Usage guidelines and recommendations] |
| Technical Considerations | | [Analysis and technical recommendations] |

In your analysis:
1. Use color names instead of hex codes.
2. Provide specific, actionable recommendations in each section.
3. Consider the interplay between all colors in the palette.
4. Balance aesthetic considerations with functional and accessibility requirements.
5. Tailor your recommendations to the gift shop, retail, museum and The Rubber Duck Museum's specific needs.
6. Focus on the strengths of the design while suggesting minor improvements.
7. Assume the design is generally well-executed and only needs fine-tuning.
8. Do not include a summary of recommendations.
"]

["help write a fanfic about the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
timeline: alternate reality, where the infinity war never happened because Thanos accidentally destroyed himself with the Power Stone.
pairings and characters: Loki/Thor (main), Tony/Pepper, Bruce/Natasha, Steve/Bucky, Clint/Laura, Peter Parker/MJ, Scott/Hope, Nick Fury, Dr. Strange, Sam Wilson, and anyone else who happened to be passing by.
genres: humor, romance (slowburn, fastburn, established relationship, as luck would have it), slice of life.
write a detailed plan for this fanfic. make the plan in a witty style.
plot: Thor returns to the Avengers. Loki unexpectedly tags along. They aren't very happy about him, remembering his past antics, but he doesn't care. Thor promises to keep both eyes on him... or rather, the one remaining one.
meanwhile, life goes on as usual. Tony proposes to Pepper. Bruce and Natasha try to rekindle their relationship. They are strongly hampered by Loki, who, firstly, still dislikes Banner for that incident with the Hulk, and secondly, ships Clintasha, because he likes to watch suffering and unrequited impossible love. Steve and Bucky just enjoy each other's company (with Sam looming somewhere nearby). Peter Parker tries to pass exams and get into the same college as MJ.

Thor honestly tries to get along with Loki, but 90% of their time together ends up in one continuous argument on everything from views on the future of Asgard to the perfect pizza topping.

and sooner or later the real motive will be revealed, why Loki decided to get involved with Thor from the very beginning.
and then it will turn out that it is a lie. and the real, very, very real Loki's real motive will be whispered into Thor's ear. or maybe Thor will knock it out of him with his fists. Or maybe both.

add lots of humor, sarcasm and romance. add fragments of dialogue and quotes", 'help write a fanfic about the marvel cinematic universe.
write a detailed plan of a fanfic on this plot. write a plan in a witty style.
timeline: alternate reality Infinity War 
Genres:  humor, crack taken seriously (almost), slice of life, a little bit of drama, lots of romance (all sorts, slowburn, fastburn, established relationships, ust, unrequited love - depending on your luck).
Pairings and characters: A LOT. Strange/Tony/Pepper(Tony's happy, Pepper... mostly happy too, Strange doesn't understand how he got into this mess), Steve/Bucky (and a "third wheel" bonus in the form of Sam), Loki/Thor(Loki calls Thor exclusively "my king", Thor acts like it's the way it should be), Bruce/Natasha(when Beauty is scarier than the Beast), Valkyrie/Jane Foster (definitely not expecting that). as well as Sam Wilson, Clint Barton, Wanda, Vision, Nick Fury, Hela, Wong, Darcy Lewis, Guardians of the Galaxy and everyone else who happened to be passing by.
write a detailed plan of a fanfic on this plot. write a plan in a witty style.
Plot: "You should have aimed for the head," Thanos smirked, prepared to snap his fingers... and lost his head. Thanks to Hela, who suddenly appeared in Wakanda with the words "only I can hurt my little brother." 
It turns out that Hela liked the joke with Surtur, so she decided to be friends with Thor. And it is even easier to come to an agreement with her than with Dormammu, so the Goddess of Death, in exchange for the Soul Stone (why would she need it?), revived Gamora, Heimdall, some others... and Loki. Because "no one can hurt my little brother except me."
So now that the universe is saved, Tony and Steve have finally had to make peace. And now all the Avengers, past and present, are pardoned and considered heroes. Bucky can’t understand why they suddenly have such sugar happiness.
The Grateful Earth gave the Asgardians an island near Norway to build New Asgard. Thor is trying to rule there as a king. And at the same time, to explain to the Midgardians, the Asgardians (and to himself, too, to be honest) why Loki and Hela are with them, alive, healthy, and not even in prison.
Life is slowly getting back to normal. Well... sort of. The Guardians of the Galaxy have returned to space (Carol occasionally reports news of them to Fury). Tony, having assessed Strange, dragged him into his relationship with Pepper, because "why is such a useful handsome man - and nobody's?". Vision was repaired, by the way, he and Wanda are doing well. Bruce tries to popularize Earth science in New Asgard, with the help of Jane Foster. Natasha tries to lure Bruce back to the Avengers. Valkyrie tries to charm Jane (successfully. It worked with Darcy too, although it was completely by accident). Clint enjoys retirement on his farm. Peter Parker helps old ladies cross the street and rescues cats from trees. Fury complains to Carol (via smartphone... or rather, Starkphone) about how life has turned from dramatic superheroics into a mix of sitcom and rom-com.

add some dialogue fragments.
add more humor, romance and lots of sarcasm', 'help write a fanfic about the marvel cinematic universe.

Plot: "You should have aimed for the head," Thanos smirked, prepared to snap his fingers... and lost his head. Thanks to Hela, who suddenly appeared in Wakanda with the words "only I can hurt my little brother." 
It turns out that Hela appreciated Ragnerok, so she decided to be friends with Thor. And it is even easier to come to an agreement with her than with Dormammu, so the Goddess of Death, in exchange for the Soul Stone (why would she need it?), revived Gamora, Heimdall, some others... and Loki. Because "no one can hurt my little brother except me."
So now that the universe is saved, Tony and Steve have finally had to make peace. And now all the Avengers, past and present, are pardoned and considered heroes. Bucky can’t understand why they suddenly have such sugar happiness.
The Grateful Earth gave the Asgardians an island near Norway to build New Asgard. Thor is trying to rule there as a king. And at the same time, to explain to the Midgardians, the Asgardians (and to himself, too, to be honest) why Loki and Hela are with them, alive, healthy, and not even in prison.
Life is slowly getting back to normal. Well... sort of. The Guardians of the Galaxy have returned to space (Carol occasionally reports news of them to Fury). Tony, having assessed Strange, dragged him into his relationship with Pepper, because "why is such a useful handsome man - and nobody's?". Vision was repaired, by the way, he and Wanda are doing well. Bruce tries to popularize Earth science in New Asgard, with the help of Jane Foster. Natasha tries to lure Bruce back to the Avengers. Valkyrie tries to charm Jane (successfully. It worked with Darcy too, although it was completely by accident). Clint enjoys retirement on his farm. Peter Parker helps old ladies cross the street and rescues cats from trees. Fury complains to Carol (via smartphone... or rather, Starkphone) about how life has turned from dramatic superheroics into a mix of sitcom and rom-com.

Perception, Action, Will: these are the three steps to turning obstacles into opportunities, adversity into advantage. By perceiving obstacles objectively, recognizing your power, and altering your perception; by acting with discipline and diligence, trusting the process; and by deploying your will, persevering no matter what – by leveraging these steps you’ll be able to transform life’s obstacles into the fire that fuels your success.', 'Teach me about alter ego How it helps to cope up with stress', 'what is an inherent weakness?', 'give me 3 paragraph on psychoanalytical theory, social learning theory, self perception theory', 'Traits of unhappiness: skepticism, meticulousness, hard disbelief, strong memory. Unhappiness linked to closed-mindedness, retention of grievances, and distrust. A sorrowful life often characterized by ease of disbelief and memory retention. Key attributes: distrust, memory accumulation, rejection of beliefs. 

Sorrowful existence optimally experienced by those who reject circumstances and remember easily. Serious disposition, meticulous mindset contribute to unhappiness. Cynicism and selective memory often lead to sorrow. 

Saddest individuals: hard disbelievers, good recall. Unhappiness found in those who distrust easily, remember vividly. A dismal life marked by skepticism and clear memory. 

Essence of unhappiness: shrewd disbelief, strong memory. Sorrow arises from distrust and retention of past grievances. 

A heavy heart common among those who reject easily and remember. Ideal traits for sorrowful life: skepticism, meticulousness, memory retention. CLUSTERING – AN OVERVIEW
 Clustering is the process of grouping a collection of objects (usually represented 
as points in a multidimensional space) into classes of similar objects. Cluster 
analysis is a very important tool in data analysis. It is a set of methodologies for 
automatic classification of a collection of patterns into clusters based on similarity. 
Intuitively, patterns within the same cluster are more similar to each other than 
patterns belonging to a different cluster. It is important to understand the difference 
between clustering (unsupervised classification) and supervised classification. 
Typical pattern clustering activity involves the following steps: 
•	
•	
•	
•	
•	
pattern	representation	(including	feature	extraction	and/or	selection),	
definition	of	a	pattern	proximity	measure	appropriate	to	the	data	domain,	
clustering
 data	abstraction	and	
assessment	of	output.	
Cluster analysis is an exploratory discovery process. It can be used to discover 
structures in data without providing an explanation/interpretation. 
Cluster analysis includes two major aspects: clustering and cluster validation. 
Clustering aims at partitioning objects into groups according to a certain criteria. To 
achieve different application purposes, a large number of clustering algorithms have 
been developed. While due to there are no general purpose clustering algorithms to 
fit all kinds of applications, thus, it is required an evaluation mechanism to assess 
the quality of clustering results that produced by different clustering algorithms or a 
clustering algorithm with different parameters, so that the user may find a fit cluster 
scheme for a specific application. The quality assessment process of clustering 
results is regarded as cluster validation. Cluster analysis is an iterative process of 
clustering and cluster verification by the user facilitated with clustering algorithms, 
cluster validation methods, visualization and domain knowledge to databases. 
Clustering is an unsupervised-based algorithm that divides a set of data points into 
clusters so that the objects are all part of the same group. Using clustering, data 
can be subdivided into smaller, more manageable groups. Data from each of these 
subgroups are grouped together into a single cluster. 
•	
•	
To	put	it	simply,	a	cluster	is	a	group	of	related	things.
 It’s	a	grouping	of	objects	where	the	distance	between	any	two	members	is	
236
 less than the distance between any two people.
•	
A	multidimensional	space	segment	with	a	high	density	of	objects	that	is	
Clustering
 related to the other segments.
 A simple example of Clustering is illustrated in Figure 1 as shown below:
 Figure 1: Example of Clustering
 Clustering helps in organizing huge voluminous data into clusters and displays 
interior structure of statistical information. Clustering is the intent of segregating 
the data into clusters. Clustering improves the data readiness towards artificial 
intelligence techniques. Process for clustering, exhibits knowledge discovery in 
data, It is used either as a stand-alone tool to get penetration into data distribution 
or as a pre-processing step for other algorithm.']

narrower_category: Impact of Climate Change on Forest Ecosystems
example_prompt:
['A resilient plant (or possibly animal) which survives or thrives in an environment which is regularly consumed by fire (e.g. by bushfires).', 'ترجمه فارسی روان و اکادمیک قابل فهم لطفا: Climate change poses significant challenges and impacts to the structure and functions of forest ecosystems worldwide. As primary sources of ecosystem production, forests play a crucial role in converting solar energy into stored organic matter, regulating biogeochemical cycles, and providing habitat for diverse species. However, rising temperatures, altered precipitation patterns, and increased frequency of extreme weather events associated with climate change are reshaping forest environments in complex ways [1][5].

The forest floor vegetation and floristic composition are particularly sensitive indicators of these changes. As the layer with the highest plant species diversity in forests, the understory vegetation responds rapidly to shifts in temperature, moisture, and other environmental factors [3]. Climate change can alter the phenology, distribution, and abundance of plant species, leading to changes in community composition and ecosystem dynamics.

Studies have shown that climate change may cause thermophilization of forest floor vegetation, where warm-adapted species increase in abundance while cool-adapted species decline [5]. This shift in species composition can have cascading effects on the entire forest ecosystem, affecting nutrient cycling, soil properties, and habitat availability for various organisms.

The impacts of climate change on forest floor vegetation and floristic composition are not uniform across regions. Local topography, soil conditions, and species interactions can modulate the effects of climate change, creating complex patterns of response [3]. Additionally, the rate and magnitude of climate change may exceed the ability of some plant species to adapt or migrate, potentially leading to local extinctions and shifts in community structure [5].

Climate change also interacts with other environmental stressors, such as deforestation and changes in land use patterns, further complicating its effects on forest ecosystems [5]. For instance, fragmentation of forest habitats can impede the ability of plant species to migrate in response to changing climatic conditions, potentially exacerbating the impacts of climate change on forest floor vegetation.

To understand and predict these impacts, researchers are increasingly utilizing climate data and modeling approaches. WorldClim bioclimatic variables, derived from monthly temperature and rainfall values, provide crucial inputs for ecological modeling [2]. These variables represent annual trends, seasonality, and extreme environmental factors that influence plant distribution and growth. For example, variables like annual mean temperature (BIO1), temperature seasonality (BIO4), and annual precipitation (BIO12) help model the suitability of habitats for different vegetation types under current and future climate scenarios [2].

Understanding these climate-driven changes in forest floor vegetation and floristic composition is crucial for several reasons. First, it provides insights into the overall health and resilience of forest ecosystems. Second, it helps predict future changes in forest biodiversity and ecosystem services. Finally, this knowledge is essential for developing effective conservation strategies and adaptive management practices in the face of ongoing climate change [6].

In conclusion, the study of climate change impacts on forest floor vegetation and floristic composition offers a powerful approach to understanding and predicting the future of forest ecosystems. This research is vital for informing conservation efforts and sustainable forest management practices in an era of rapid environmental change [7].', 'متن زیر را ترجمه فارسی روان و اکادمیک کن  و هم خلاصه کن و هدفشون رو بگو و روش کار رو بیان کن و نتایج را نیز بگو : Forests provide a range of ecosystem services essential for human wellbeing. In a changing climate, forest management is expected to play a fundamental role by preserving the functioning of forest ecosystems and enhancing the adaptive processes. Understanding and quantifying the future forest coverage in view of climate changes is therefore crucial in order to develop appropriate forest management strategies. However, the potential impacts of climate change on forest ecosystems remain largely unknown due to the uncertainties lying behind the future prediction of models. To fill this knowledge gap, here we aim to provide an uncertainty assessment of the potential impact of climate change on the forest coverage in Italy using species distribution modelling technique. The spatial distribution of 19 forest tree species in the country was extracted from the last national forest inventory and modelled using nine Species Distribution Models algorithms, six different Global Circulation Models (GCMs), and one Regional Climate Models (RCMs) for 2050s under an intermediate forcing scenario (RCP 4.5). The single species predictions were then compared and used to build a future forest cover map for the country. Overall, no sensible variation in the spatial distribution of the total forested area was predicted with compensatory effects in forest coverage of different tree species, whose magnitude and patters appear largely modulated by the driving climate models. The analyses reported an unchanged amount of total land suitability to forest growth in mountain areas while smaller values were predicted for valleys and floodplains than high-elevation areas. Pure woods were predicted as the most influenced when compared with mixed stands which are characterized by a greater species richness and, therefore, a supposed higher level of biodiversity and resilience to climate change threatens. Pure softwood stands along the Apennines chain in central Italy (e.g., Pinus, Abies) were more sensitive than hardwoods (e.g., Fagus, Quercus) and generally characterized by pure and even-aged planted forests, much further away from their natural structure where admixture with other tree species is more likely. In this context a sustainable forest management strategy may reduce the potential impact of climate change on forest ecosystems. Silvicultural practices should be aimed at increasing the species richness and favoring hardwoods currently growing as dominating species under conifers canopy, stimulating the natural regeneration, gene flow, and supporting (spatial) migration processes.', 'Climate change also interacts with other environmental stressors, such as deforestation and changes in land use patterns, further complicating its effects on forest ecosystems [5]. For instance, fragmentation of forest habitats can impede the ability of plant species to migrate in response to changing climatic conditions, potentially exacerbating the impacts of climate change on forest floor vegetation.

To understand and predict these impacts, researchers are increasingly utilizing climate data and modeling approaches. WorldClim bioclimatic variables, derived from monthly temperature and rainfall values, provide crucial inputs for ecological modeling [2]. These variables represent annual trends, seasonality, and extreme environmental factors that influence plant distribution and growth. For example, variables like annual mean temperature (BIO1), temperature seasonality (BIO4), and annual precipitation (BIO12) help model the suitability of habitats for different vegetation types under current and future climate scenarios [2].

Understanding these climate-driven changes in forest floor vegetation and floristic composition is crucial for several reasons. First, it provides insights into the overall health and resilience of forest ecosystems. Second, it helps predict future changes in forest biodiversity and ecosystem services. Finally, this knowledge is essential for developing effective conservation strategies and adaptive management practices in the face of ongoing climate change [6].

In conclusion, the study of climate change impacts on forest floor vegetation and floristic composition offers a powerful approach to understanding and predicting the future of forest ecosystems. This research is vital for informing conservation efforts and sustainable forest management practices in an era of rapid environmental change [7].ترجمه فارسی روان و اکادمیک قابل فهم لطفا:', 'به صورت پاراگرافی باشد متن زیر را ترجمه فارسی روان و اکادمیک کن هم خلاصه کن و فقط هدفشون رو بگو و روش کار رو بیان کن و نتایج را نیز بگو :Abstract
A predictive understanding of interactions between vegetation and climate has been a grand challenge in terrestrial ecology for over 200 years. Developed in recent decades, continental-scale monitoring of climate and forest dynamics enables quantitative examination of vegetation–climate relationships through a data-driven paradigm. Here, we apply a data-intensive approach to investigate forest–climate interactions across the conterminous USA. We apply multivariate statistical methods (stepwise regression, principal component analysis) including machine learning to infer significant climatic drivers of standing forest basal area. We focus our analysis on the ecoregional scale. For most ecoregions analyzed, both stepwise regression and random forests indicate that factors related to precipitation are the most significant predictors of forest basal area. In almost half of US ecoregions, precipitation of the coldest quarter is the single most important driver of basal area. The demonstrated data-driven approach may be used to inform forest-climate envelope modeling and the forecasting of large-scale forest dynamics under climate change scenarios. These results have important implications for climate, biodiversity, industrial forestry, and indigenous communities in a changing world.', 'Climate change also interacts with other environmental stressors, such as deforestation and changes in land use patterns, further complicating its effects on forest ecosystems [5]. For instance, fragmentation of forest habitats can impede the ability of plant species to migrate in response to changing climatic conditions, potentially exacerbating the impacts of climate change on forest floor vegetation.

To understand and predict these impacts, researchers are increasingly utilizing climate data and modeling approaches. WorldClim bioclimatic variables, derived from monthly temperature and rainfall values, provide crucial inputs for ecological modeling [2]. These variables represent annual trends, seasonality, and extreme environmental factors that influence plant distribution and growth. For example, variables like annual mean temperature (BIO1), temperature seasonality (BIO4), and annual precipitation (BIO12) help model the suitability of habitats for different vegetation types under current and future climate scenarios [2].

Understanding these climate-driven changes in forest floor vegetation and floristic composition is crucial for several reasons. First, it provides insights into the overall health and resilience of forest ecosystems. Second, it helps predict future changes in forest biodiversity and ecosystem services. Finally, this knowledge is essential for developing effective conservation strategies and adaptive management practices in the face of ongoing climate change [6].

In conclusion, the study of climate change impacts on forest floor vegetation and floristic composition offers a powerful approach to understanding and predicting the future of forest ecosystems. This research is vital for informing conservation efforts and sustainable forest management practices in an era of rapid environmental change [7].ترجمه فارسی روان و اکادمیک قابل فهم لطفا:', 'ترجمه فارسی روان و اکادمیک قابل فهم لطفا: Climate change poses significant challenges and impacts to the structure and functions of forest ecosystems worldwide. WorldClim bioclimatic variables, derived from monthly temperature and rainfall values, provide crucial inputs for ecological modeling [2]. These variables represent annual trends, seasonality, and extreme environmental factors that influence plant distribution and growth. For example, variables like annual mean temperature (BIO1), temperature seasonality (BIO4), and annual precipitation (BIO12) help model the suitability of habitats for different vegetation types under current and future climate scenarios [2].

Understanding these climate-driven changes in forest floor vegetation and floristic composition is crucial for several reasons. First, it provides insights into the overall health and resilience of forest ecosystems. Second, it helps predict future changes in forest biodiversity and ecosystem services. Finally, this knowledge is essential for developing effective conservation strategies and adaptive management practices in the face of ongoing climate change [6].

In conclusion, the study of climate change impacts on forest floor vegetation and floristic composition offers a powerful approach to understanding and predicting the future of forest ecosystems. This research is vital for informing conservation efforts and sustainable forest management practices in an era of rapid environmental change [7].', '以科技论文写作的要求提升英语表达，以达到子刊正刊的水准：Throughout the decay
